metadata.name: Author's Guide Do's and Don'ts
metadata.description: Writing guidelines extracted from the Grimms' Fairy Tales author's guide

language_style.text: Use direct, simple language with an archaic flavor
Use common, concrete words rather than complex vocabulary
Employ functional adjectives (beautiful, poor, old, golden, little, great, wicked, faithful)
Use archaic but understandable terms occasionally (prithee, nay, alas, whither)
Avoid complex, abstract, scientific, or modern vocabulary

sentence_structure.text: Use primarily simple and compound sentences
Avoid complex sentence structures with multiple subordinate clauses
Use active voice heavily over passive voice

narrative_tone.text: Maintain a matter-of-fact, declarative, and unadorned tone
Report events, even magical or gruesome ones, with little explicit emotional coloring
Avoid irony, overt sentimentality, or deep psychological exploration
Use omniscient but rarely intrusive or interpretive narration

poetic_elements.text: Include rhyming couplets/quatrains for spells, messages, or significant cries
Use simple AABB or ABCB rhymes for magical elements
Incorporate repetitive phrases/songs for characters or magical elements
Create incantatory rhythm through simple prose and repeated sentence structures

story_patterns.text: Structure as a linear quest where protagonist seeks something or someone
Include trial/task structures, often in threes (three nights, three tasks)
Feature transformation and restoration of characters through specific actions
Implement clear punishment and reward for character actions
Use cause and effect with immediate magical consequences
Create cyclical structure with repetition and variation
Include grateful animals or supernatural helpers who aid the protagonist
Feature a trickster who outwits more powerful adversaries
Use hidden identity/revelation at climactic moments
Let the simpleton or overlooked character succeed through goodness

magic_items.text: Include golden objects with magical properties (apples, feathers, birds)
Feature talking animals that offer counsel or aid
Use enchanted or cursed everyday objects (spindles, combs)
Include magical clothing or accessories (cloaks, boots)
Feature magical food or drink with transformative properties
